settings.title: How to Install Square Edge/PSE Cladding Like a Pro
settings.text:
Square Edge, also known as Planed Square Edge (PSE) cladding, is a versatile and sleek choice for finishing both interior and exterior walls. Its clean lines and simple design make it ideal for modern or minimalist projects, while its ease of installation makes it a great option for DIY enthusiasts and professionals alike.

Square Edge cladding provides excellent weather resistance and a smooth, contemporary finish. Whether you're working on a garden building, shed, or home facade, proper installation is key to ensuring a polished and long-lasting result. Follow this step-by-step guide to tackle your Square Edge cladding project with confidence!

settings.overlay_text: Use this section to welcome customers to your store, show off your images or display a promotion

settings.title: Why Choose Square Edge/PSE Cladding?
settings.text:
Square Edge cladding stands out for its clean, straight lines and understated elegance. Its design makes it highly adaptable, suiting both traditional and modern structures. Plus, with its smooth finish, it’s easy to stain, paint, or leave untreated to achieve your desired look. Durable and easy to install, Square Edge cladding is an excellent choice for a wide variety of projects.

Tools and Materials You’ll Need

Before you get started, gather these essentials:

  • Square Edge cladding boards
    Don’t forget to include trims for a professional finish at corners and edges.
  • Treated timber battens: Provides the foundation for securely attaching your cladding.
  • Fixings: Stainless steel screws or nails are best to prevent corrosion.
  • Breathable membrane: Protects against moisture ingress while allowing airflow to prevent rot.
  • Drill or nail gun: Speeds up the fixing process.
  • Saw (hand or power): For trimming boards to the required length.
  • Spirit level and tape measure: Ensures accurate cuts and alignment.
  • Weatherproof finish: Oil, stain, or paint (optional but recommended).
  • Safety gear: Goggles, gloves, and other protective equipment.

Step 1: Surface Preparation

Start by preparing the wall for cladding installation:

  • Inspect the surface: Ensure it’s clean, dry, and stable.
  • Attach a breathable membrane: Temporarily secure it with tape, then fix it properly using galvanized staples, nails, or screws with washers. This acts as a weather-resistant barrier and allows ventilation.

Step 2: Install the Battens

Treated timber battens are essential for supporting your cladding.

  • Measure and mark: For horizontal Square Edge cladding, position vertical battens.
  • Spacing: Space battens evenly, 400–600mm apart, with extra battens at corners, around windows, and along edges for additional support.
  • Secure battens: Fix them securely to the wall using screws or fasteners appropriate for your wall type.

Step 3: Prepare the Square Edge Boards

  • Inspect your boards: Check for any defects and let the boards acclimate to site conditions for 5–7 days to reduce movement after installation.
  • Cut to size: Use a saw to trim the boards to the required length, leaving a 2mm gap at edges to allow for expansion.

Step 4: Start Cladding

Now you’re ready to start installing the boards!

  • Begin at the bottom: For horizontal cladding, start at the base of the wall; for vertical cladding, begin at one side.
  • Check alignment: Use a spirit level to ensure the first board is perfectly straight.

Step 5: Fix the Boards

  • Secure the first board: Fix it to the battens using stainless steel screws or nails. Ensure the fixings are evenly spaced and flush with the board for a neat finish.
  • Continue upwards: Attach subsequent boards, ensuring they are evenly spaced for a uniform appearance. Square Edge cladding does not overlap, so precise alignment is key to achieving a sleek finish.

Step 6: Finishing Touches

  • Trim as needed: Neatly cut boards to fit around windows, doors, and other openings.
  • Add trims and mouldings: Use edge trims and corner mouldings to give your project a clean, professional finish.

Step 7: Protect Your Timber

To maintain the beauty and durability of your Square Edge cladding:

  • Apply a protective finish: Use an oil, stain, or paint to preserve the timber’s natural color and protect against weathering.
  • Reapply as necessary: Regular maintenance will help your cladding last for years to come.
